name: Canada Day Picnic
description:
Get ready to rock your red and white with us!

Join us live on location for loads of food, fun and good tunes! 

We’re featuring rock and roll tributes to the best bands in the world. Then we’ll cap off Canada Day with Toronto’s largest fireworks display from Ashbridges Bay, set to a “live” set of amazing Rock! 

Come down and enjoy the Kids Zone with arts and crafts, great eats, a Beer Garden and most of all... rock and roll!

name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Masterworks
description:
The Southern Netherlands — better known today as Flanders — was home to revolutionary artists. These extraordinary painters found new ways to depict reality, portray humanity, and tell stories that created parallels to their world then - and to our world today. 

This large-scale exhibition, featuring over 80 stunning art works and objects — medieval, Renaissance, and baroque paintings, sculptures and more — offers a doorway into the Southern Netherlands of 1400 to 1700. The exhibition's unique presentation introduces the visitor, through these rare, extraordinary artworks, to stories of enterprising townspeople, prosperous cities, and an ever-developing society.

name: Canada Day at Gibson House
description: Celebrate Canada Day at Gibson House and experience a day filled with creativity, culture and community spirit.

name: Canada Day Comedy - 100% Canadian Beef
description:
Featuring six diverse, polite, yet hilariously petty all-star Canadian comedians — because that’s the true Canadian way.

Headliners include Ryan Belleville from Working Moms and The Late Late Show, Leonard Chan from Just For Laughs, Allie Pearse from Letterkenny, Nick Reynoldson from Just For Laughs, Hannah Veldhoen from JFL Toronto. Hosted by Daniel Woodrow of Roast Battle Canada.

name: East York Canada Day Festival

location.name: Parade begins at Dieppe Park and ends at Stan Wadlow Park

description:
Rain or shine, come celebrate our famous 69th community parade and event! Hosting a slew of entertainers, food vendors, kids activities and a beer garden, there is something for everyone. 

Volunteer sign-up encouraged, please see website for more details.

name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Museum
description:
Beginning July 1st, experience "Making Home in Scarborough," a vibrant pop-up installation that celebrates memory, identity, and belonging through community voices, cultural expression, and shared experiences of place.

This pop-up exhibit is rooted in ideas of home which are often rooted in memory, place, community, cultural traditions and objects we hold dear to our hearts in generations past, present and future. Co-created through conversation and care, Making Home in Scarborough celebrates the creativity, resilience, and traditions that shape our communities. As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?" If you live in Scarborough, "What does Making Home in Scarborough Mean to you?"

We are grateful for our community collaborators: Native Child and Family Services / Scarborough Child & Family Life Centre, Malvern Family Resource Centre, TDSB Newcomer Services (Malvern), Toby's Place, Scarborough Museum Youth Collective and Change Made.

name: Making Home in Scarborough - Event at Scarborough Museum
description:
Join Scarborough Museum this July 1st for a vibrant celebration of culture, connection, and the meaningful ways communities create and carry a sense of home. Rooted in the stories, traditions, and cultural practices that shape our everyday lives, this year’s event honours how Scarborough's diverse communities have inherited and continue to preserve belonging through cherished objects, craft, movement, and food.

Honour the closing of ReDress by waⁿdat utrihǫt Catherine Tàmmaro and the launch of two powerful pop-up exhibits, a nourishing shared meal, hands-on creative activities, and joyful moments that bring us together across generations and cultures.

We are grateful for our community collaborators: Native Child and Family Services / Scarborough Child & Family Life Centre, Malvern Family Resource Centre, TDSB Newcomer Services (Malvern), Toby's Place, Scarborough Museum Youth Collective, Change Made, Hatecopy and TÀMMARO ART/Design.

name: Washed Up: Pop-Up Installation at Scarborough Museum
description:
Beginning July 1st at Scarborough Museum, experience Washed Up by Hatecopy. The project captures the essence of liminal spaces that serve as cultural hubs for the South Asian immigrant communities, using the washing machine as a vessel to carry textiles that signify our roots and drawing visitors into an environment that intertwines the past, present, and future; acknowledging the dirty laundry of Canadian History and “Truth,” and reclaiming both seen and unseen spaces.

Maria Qamar (b. 1991) is a Toronto-based pop artist whose work is focused in the South Asian diaspora and immigrant communities and their cultural experiences. The work specializes in themes regarding feminism, social change, humour, pop culture, politics and romance. The artist has been recognized both nationally and internationally with exhibits and features in the Museum of Contemporary Arts, the National Arts Centre, Sotheby’s, Phillips Auction, and the AGO.

name: Proud to be Canadian: Celebrating Chinese Communities
description:
"Celebrate the vibrancy of Toronto’s Chinese communities with programming that will include dancing, singing, face painting, food demonstrations and tastings, storytelling and more!
"
